title: coronavirus shows we got out just in time now someone switch the eu ventilator off
story: But there’s one thing the pandemic has made absolutely clear — we were right, beyond all doubt, to leave the European Union.The EU is in desperate trouble. Its vast bureaucratic institutions were utterly unable to react to the threat of the virus.So the inidual countries did it all for themselves. Each following a dferent policy. When the moment came, the EU was found wanting. Lethargic, hopeless and riven with internal dispute.There is fury in Spain that the EUwon’t bung them loads of money for being badly hit by the virus.It’s the same in Italy, where  per cent of the population now want to LEAVE the EU. The country that was usually one of the EU’s biggest cheerleaders.A disillusion with the EU is spreading across the continent.People are beginning to see that it’s a good thing to have control of your borders. And that the best way of controlling those borders is through a nation state.The Greeks have been trying to contain a mass influx of refugees from Turkey — and getting no help from the EU in the process. Some senior EU politicians fear that the virus could kill off the EU altogether. Right now it’s on a ventilator and looking very sorry for itself.We can only hope — for the good of our European friends — that someone switches that ventilator off.Once we all emerge from lockdown there will be a financial price to pay. Our economy — the world’s economy — has taken a hell of a battering.But the good news is that we will be in with a much better chance of a full recovery than the EU bloc.From  you will no longer have to pay tarfs on a vast range of goods imported from beyond Europe.I suspect it will lead to a consumer bonanza — which is just what we want. Washing machines, freezers, women’s sanitary products, bicycle inner tubes, Christmas trees — the list of stuff which will be cheaper is almost endless.It’s true thatthe EU refuses to soften its stance about a trade deal with us, then we’ll pay more for cars made on the continent.But even that might have its upside. It will encourage people to buy British. Last year Brits bought only , cars that had been manufactured in the UK. The majority of cars were bought from German plants. Your loss, Germany.The EU negotiators are still being intransigent. They still think they can bully this country.Michael Gove has told them to get real. Sort out an acceptable trade deal for the good of the entire European economy.But eventhey don’t — evenreality fails to establish itself inside their closed minds— it will be the EU that loses out.It wouldn’t surprise me hugelyCovid- outlasted the European Union, frankly. We should all breathe a sigh of relief that we got the hell out of that helpless institution.Just in time.I WONDERCovid- will see an end to hard cash  My local shopkeepers tell me that almost no transactions in the past two months have been paid in cash. It’s all done by card.I’ve had the same  quid in my pocket that was there on March .I bet we don’t go back to paying in cash once this is over. Queuing for ages behind some addled berk at the ATM who is incapable of pressing the right buttons. Cash is going the way of the dinosaurs.And it’s not too far of a stretch to suggest that offices might be on their way out, either. Hugely expensive things to run, offices. And the original reason we had them was to store paper – files and so on. Don’t really need that any more, do we  People have discovered that working from home has many benefits. Not least the pleasure of avoiding pointless meetings with idiots.And for those who feel the need to get away from their families on a daily basis there’s “co-working environments”, or “the park with a load of booze”, as I like to call it.MOST lady slebs are busy during lockdown taking pictures of themselves wearing almost no clothes.Either to advertise products nobody really wants or to advertise themselves. For which many thanks, girls.Scarcely a day goes by without one of them taking a perfectly natural selfie of herself with hardly any clothes on, pouting at the camera like a trout with a botched facelt.Model Rosie Huntington-Whiteley has gone a stage further and posted pics of herself taken  years ago. Just in case we’d forgotten.I might get in on the act. Next week I’ll take a selfie wearing a leather thong and nipple clamps, advertising my new skincare product made from vole’s urine.Watch this space.I’m not so sure. Boredom is a greatly underrated virtue. It makes you get off your backside and do something. And our kids have been bored senseless for two months now.You never know, this break might do the kids some good. Fire their imaginations or something.And better still – it means they’re not having left-wing drivel drilled into their heads by the teachers…THE English Football League is in a right old mess.None of its three isions can agree what to do about finishing the season.The clubs in the lowest tier, ision two, have voted to end the season immediately. Those in the Championship want to finish the season, while League One clubs haven’t a clue.There’s talk of Coventry and Rotherham being promoted and a play-off between the next EIGHT clubs.I know a lot of money is at stake. I know the league has signed big deals with the broad- casters. But the sensible thing surely would have been to call the season null and void, across all three isions.Those of us who, like me, support clubs who had a chance of promotion will get over our disappointment.There are more important things than football.So let’s look at Sweden. It became the country with the highest death rate per capita from Covid- in Europe during thesevendays to May .The lockdown has unquestionably saved lives.LAST Friday night I was called  times in the space of an hour by the SAME NUMBER.What’s more, my phone told me the call was coming from Tajikistan. But every time I tried to answer, the caller hung up. That’s totally unfair.I have never in my le spoken to a person from Tajikistan. And I would very much like to do so. It might be interesting.I’m sure it was a criminal of some kind, but that’s not the point.I wanted to knowmy caller was a member of the mysterious Yaghnobi people, who live in the mountains in the north of the country, with their many goats. That would have been exciting.I might start ringing up numbers in Tajikistan indiscriminately. And then move on to Kyrgyzstan.That’s what lockdown does to you.For this they have been attacked by “human rights activists”.Perhaps.But not by the people of Hungary, who fully agree with this measure.Much as I suspect people would over here.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: builder turn down tea peoples homes
story: BUILDERS must turn down tea and biscuitsthey are offered them while working in people’s houses, according to new safety guidelines.Electricians, plumbers and other workers must also ask permission to use your loo — and bring their own soap and towels. And they must strictly remain two metres apart.It is traditional for householders to offer a mug of “builder’s tea” to workers in their homes.But in future they must bring their own brew, warns the Competent Roofer trade body.They must also avoid taking breaks in the house, steer clear of shops, eat outsideweather allows and sanitise their hands before and after eating.LUNCH AND TEA BREAKSIf they eat in their van they must clean all surfaces and controls touched.The body’s manager Tracie Hunter said: “Sadly you can’t invite tradespeople into your home for a cuppa.“But don’t stop coming up with other safe ways to show your appreciation.”Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: cops last known cctv image tesco
story: The CCTV still shows Louise Smith at a Tesco supermarket the night before she disappeared from her home in Havant, Hants, on VE Day.Louse was last seen around midday on May  after telling pals she was popping out briefly.She was due tohome to spend the weekend with her boyfriend, who had come over to stay.Detectives managed to trace her mobile phone to a skate park before it was switched off two hours later.Cops have released CCTV of Louise captured at a Tescostore on Greywell Road that she visited around .pm on May .Officers hunting for the missing youngster hope the photos will jog someones memory.A man and woman, both , were arrested on suspicion of kidnap last Friday have now been released on bail.Volunteers from the Isle of Wight Search and Rescue team have also joined the hunt in Hampshire, Berkshire, Sussex and Surrey.After her phone was switched off around pm on that day, family had said, Louise had not been seen or heard from despite constant door-to-door inquiries being carried out by police.Louise is described as: white, around ft ins tall, slim, and straight, black, shoulder- hair.Detectives urged residents in Leigh Park to check their CCTV in case the schooolgirl appears on it.A spokesman for Hampshire Constabulary said:  As part of our ongoing inquiries to find Louise, we are not only trying to trace her movements since this time, but also in the previous  hours, so that we have a clear understanding of where she had been and who she may have spoken to.We know she was in the Tescostore, in Greywell Road, shortly before .pm the night before she was reported missing, Thursday May , and we are today able to share that image with you, in the hope it may jog your memory.Perhaps you saw her on Thursday May , either before or after she was in the store Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: siberia heatwave hottest spring
story: Temperatures soared in the foothills of the Altai Mountain foothills shattering May weather records and sparking shocking wildfires.To keep cool during the unseasonal scorcher locals have been hitting lakeside beaches in a region more famous as the coldest inhabited place on the planet.Areas in western Siberia have reported temperatures of C to C -  far hotter than typical for the time of year.In one of many freak weather consequences, ice at Arctic port of Dudinka on the Yenisei River melted a full month before its usual time of early June.To the south in Kransoyarsk ticks are swarming some  times more than normal, carrying the threat of encephalitis and Lyme disease.More than , people have reported tick bites in Kemerovo region, and further west in Tyumen doctors have registered  cases a day, said head of regional infectious hospital Galina PolushkinaA record number of wildfires have raged earlier than usual in Siberia, with hundreds of houses and two million hectares destroyed by the end of April.There are fears for harvests due to the excessive early heat.Apple and cherry trees which normally bloom at the end of May were in full blossom in late April.Its like there was no spring and we moved from the end of winter with metres-high piles of snow straight into summer, radio journalist Sergey Zubchuk told The Siberian Times.There was no spring, no weeks-long gentle rise of temperature. Somebody just clicked the hot air switch at the end of April, and summer began.Im Siberian-born and lived here for  years, I dont remember a single spring like this.Experts predict anomalous warm temperatures - up to C higher than typical - in western Siberia and the Arctic Circle in the coming days.Overall, Russia averaged C above normal during the first four months of .Oil city Surgut reported C in mid-May, some ten degrees above the norm.The heat wave came to us from the southwest, almost Iran, said Professor Alexey Kozhukhovskiy for the Siberian Federal University.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: pub landlords demand two metre rule is halved 37000
story: PUB landlords have demanded that the two-metre social distancing rule is halved because it could leave over , boozers unable to open.The industry’s largest trade association has said the majority of pubs could openthe rule is changed, but that  per cent would otherwise stay closed.Industry leaders have claimed that companies will be bankruptedstaff and customers have to keep two metres apart.Ministers have said that some areas of the hospitality industry could start to open in July, but that social distancing measures will be implemented.George Eustice, the environment secretary, said government was “working with the hospitality and pub sector to identy what social distancing measures they might be able to put in place”.This could see only large pubs or those with gardens allowed to reopen.The sector’s largest trade body, however, has warned this would wreak havoc on the industry.Emma McClarkin, chief executive of the British Beer and Pub Association, told The Times that “at two metres you’re probably looking at only  per cent of pubs being able to operate.”With an estimated , pubs and bars in the UK, this could see over , forced to keep their doors closed.Ms McClarkin noted, however, that a one-metre rule “would put the majority of pubs back in play”.She added: “It becomes extraordinarily dficult without some flexibility in the guidelines. There are pubs that haven’t even got a two-metre radius around the bar so that rules them out.”The UK and Spain are the only European countries using a two-metre rule, with the World Health Organisation recommending one metre.David Moore, the owner of Michelin starred Pied à Terre in London, said the current rule “would be a disaster” for the industry.He said that the government should “trust operators to get it right, we don’t want to endanger our team or our customers.”Proposals to reopen the sector were released by UKHospitality yesterday.The -page document said that drinkers will be banned from standing at bars, and suggested that restaurants get rid of salt and pepper shakers.Their recommendations also included using contactless ordering through an app, staff wearing masks and gloves and social distancing signage on the walls and floor.It comes as some pub owners have started serving booze in takeaway glasses and bottles.Pictures posted on social media show people downing their first drinks from their locals since pubs and bars were closed on March .Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: uk reject eu border post demand
story: Government documents published on Wednesday confirmed there will need to be checks on some goods entering Northern Ireland from the rest of the UK from January next year once the Brexit transition period has ended.But it rejected the EU’s demands for new infrastructure to be introduced to carry out the checks. Instead they will expand existing border screening to carry out the additional checks.And the government documents made clear that the checks will be conducted by UK border officials, snubbing EU demands to have their own personnel carrying out checks.It set up another big row with Brussels, which wanted to install a permanent base in Northern Ireland to oversee the checks.But Cabinet Office Minister Michael Gove, who unveiled the UK plans in the Commons on Wednesday, admitted that Northern Ireland will have to follow EU rules on agriculture and manufactured goods until at least .The key concession will ensure access to the EU’s single market and keep the border with the Republic of Ireland free-flowing in order to maintain the Northern Ireland Peace Agreement.The Government paper said having a so-called “mini-EU embassy” in Belfast would be “isive” and called on Brussels to “respect the UK’s territorial integrity”.It also promised Northern Ireland businesses would benefit from “unfettered access” when selling goods to the rest of the UK. It ended a row over whether checks would be in place on goods entering the UK from Northern Ireland.Mr Gove, minister in charge of Brexit preparations, said: Our proposals will deliver unfettered access for Northern Ireland businesses to the whole of the UK market ensure there are no tarfs on goods remaining within the UK customs territory discharge our obligations without the need for any new customs infrastructure in Northern Ireland and, finally, guarantee that Northern Ireland businesses benefit from the lower tarfs we deliver through our new free trade agreements with third countries.The plans were given a cautious initial welcome by the EU last night, who said they will be monitoring the implementation of the Northern Ireland Protocol closely.A European Commission spokesman said: “The detailed legal commitments set out in the Protocol must now be implemented precisely to give full effect to this solution.The time to implement the Protocol is short, and practical implementation measures must start immediately so that the Protocol can be operational by  January . To this end, the Commission stands ready to work with the UK authorities.”In a further sign of relations souring between the two sides, the EU’s chief negotiator Michel Barnier last night hit out at the “tone” of his opposite number David Frost.He said a “new dynamism” was needed in talksthe two sides are to avoid a “stalemate”.Mr Barnier was hitting back at a furious letter from Mr Frost that was highly critical of the EU’s rigid approach to the negotiations.Mr Frost said Brussels proposed deal contains novel and unbalanced proposals which would bind this country to EU law or standards.He said: What is on offer is not a fair free trade relationship between close economic partners, but a relatively low-quality trade agreement coming with unprecedented EU oversight of our laws and institutions.”In his reply, Mr Barnier said he did not think an exchange of letters regarding the substance of the negotiations is necessarily the best way to discuss on substantial points.He added: It cannot be a substitute for serious engagement and detailed negotiations and, in particular, I would not like the tone that you have taken to impact the mutual trust and constructive attitude that is essential between us.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. story: NewsBuild new Royal Navy supply ships in the UK with British steel, Tories are urgedEXCLUSIVE: Amid rising hopes UK firms will win the deal for new Fleet Solid Support ships, campaigners call for British steel to be used in constructionShareCommentsByBen GlazeDeputy Political Editor:,  MAY NewsThe Fleet Solid Support Ship programme is worth £.billion" to FREE email alerts from Mirror - politicsSubscribeWhen you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailCampaigners today urge ministers to boost British industry by handing a £.billion shipbuilding contract to a UK yard – and use British steel.With workers furloughed, orders running dry and the country mired in a coronavirus recession, unions, MPs and sector leaders called on the Government to inject optimism into two key industries.The Ministry of Defence dramatically halted a procurement scheme for three Fleet Solid Support ships last year amid a furious row about the involvement of foreign firms. The vital vessels will resupply Royal Navy aircraft carriers, destroyers and frigates. For national security reasons, Royal Navy warships can only be built in the UK.But because the supply ships will be part of the Royal Fleet Auxiliary, they are not classed as warships – meaning they could be built abroad. The competition for the contract was offered worldwide, with companies from Italy, Spain, Japan and South Korea shortlisted along with a UK consortium. The British team, backed by the Keep Britain Afloat campaign, included Babcock, BAE Systems, Cammell Laird and Rolls-Royce. The prospect of building British naval ships abroad when the UK was leaving the EU and reasserting itself globally horried campaigners and triggered a split in government. The tendering process was stopped abruptly in November – raising hopes the terms could be reset to boost British firmsapos chances of winning the deal.  Experts believe the UK team is now favourite to secure the contract, and hope a decision will be made before the end of the year. Labour called on the Government to inject much-needed optimism into the sector and make an announcement now – giving British steelmakers enough time to draw up bids to supply metal for the vesselsapos hulls. Shadow Defence Secretary John Healey said: When thousands are out of work and businesses are struggling due to coronavirus, the Ministry of Defence should be spending and building in the UK to help support British jobs.  The Government must now commit to building future Royal Navy and Royal Fleet Auxiliary vessels, including the Fleet Solid Support ships, in British shipyards and to buying British, so that our world-leading industries like steel are first in line to supply the parts to build these ships. GMB national officer Ross Murdoch, who is also maritime chairman of the Confederation of Shipbuilding and Engineering Unions, said: “At a time of national crisis when two million people are projected to lose their jobs, this £.billion contract should be awarded to UK yards to give the economy the shot in the arm that it desperately needs. “We need to ensure that as much British material is used to build these ships as possible. “This contract would be a vital boost to our strategic industries, including steel. “It is time to build back up the UKaposs strategic manufacturing capabilities, and keeping this contract in this country would be the first step towards achieving that aim.” Community steelworkersapos union operations director Alasdair McDiarmid said: “The Government should award this deal to the UK shipyard and then ensure as much British steel is used as possible.  “It’s important that the procurement is done the right way, which means giving UK steel producers enough notice of the specications and requirements so they are able to supply the steel that’s needed. “These major projects should be an opportunity to boost vital industries and support our manufacturing communities, especially during these challenging times.” UK Steel director-general Gareth Stace said: “UK steel producers have the capacity and capability to supply high-quality steel into projects such as this.

You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailPlans to reopen schools have been plunged into chaos - as a government minister admits Englandaposs primaries might not all open on June . Englandaposs primaries were told to prepare to bring back year R,  and  pupils back to class, with other primary years ing later in June.  But those plans were hurled into doubt by a mass revolt from unions and councils. Liverpool, Hartlepool, Birmingham, and even Tory-run Solihull and Essex have warned June  might not be possible. Some are looking at later dates, some are still waiting to see what will happen, and some are suggesting s may be part-time - despite the government saying this isnapost an option.Schools are of course already open for vulnerable children and those of key workers. But plans to open them more widely - which involves halving class sizes, hiding away toys, having staggered breaks and making corridors one-way - have ided many in the teaching profession. They need time to prepare, and also want to see the full scientic evidence on whether itaposll be safe. Scientists have also said the government should wait until after a delayed test, track and trace app is up and running. AskedLabour would back councils refusing to open on June , a spokesman for Keir Starmer said: “Ultimately councils will want to do what is in the best interests of children and families in their respective area. The infection rate ies from area to area so it’s not surprising some councils have particular concerns.” The government has insisted the June  date was at the earliest and schools wouldnapost be reopenedit was unsafe. Today one minister, Robert Buckland, admitted they may not open unormly across England. In Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland they will remain shut to the wider population. So what have dissenting councils in England said  Hereaposs what we know so far. These are all the areas weaposve found so far expressing doubt about the governmentaposs plans. But the situation is changing fast so itaposs inevitable some are probably left out. If you know one which should be added to this list, please e-mail dan.bloom@mirror. Barking and Dagenham Council leader Darren Rowell: “I cannot support any school reopeningit puts at risk the safety of our teachers, staff and young people.. Simply forcing schools to reopen without taking steps to reduce the risk of the virus spread is unacceptable… We can’t put people at risk by rushing back to normality before it’s safe.” Birmingham We only support Birmingham schools opening to more pupils when it is safe to do so. We are committed to having due regard to the guidance that has been issued by the government. However, we recognise that for some schools, opening to more pupils safely may not be possible on  June.  Bradford Bradford Council has no intention of directing schools to open on June  or to force parents to send their children back and we are committed to working in partnership with school leaders, families and trade unions so that they can make sure their schools are safe environments for our children whenever they choose to open. Parents will not be finedthey choose not to send their children back to school at this time. Brighton and Hove We have strongly advised our schools that they should only reopen to more children when their risk assessments indicate it is safe to do so. It is likely that wider re-opening will happen at dferent times for dferent schools and for dferent numbers of children, given each school’s particular circumstances. Bristol Mayor Marvin Rees: You cannot just make a blanket statement on Bristol. What we’ve said is we will back our schools to make the decision they have to make. Bury While high levels of Covid- infection in the north west remain, and guidance around practical arrangements for social distancing within educational environments, testing and tracing, and supply of PPE is unclear, the borough will not be re-opening schools on June .  Calderdale Adam Wilkinson, lead member for children and young people: We are advising schools in Calderdale not to extend opening on  June. We are keen to get more pupils back to school, but safety is of paramount importance  we have been advised by public health professionals that governments key tests have not been met. Durham Schools in County Durham are being advised that they should only start a phased reopening when they feel it is safe to do so.  Essex Whilst all schools are working hard to respond to the guidance provided by the Department for Education, depending on each inidual school context, some primary, infant and junior schools may not be able to offer full-time provision for the relevant year groups, and any new arrangements may not be introduced exactly from the st June. Gateshead We have absolute confidence that each school will determine the risk, and will make the right decision for their schools, pupils, staff and parents. The council will fully support any school that after careful consideration of all these factors, determines that they cannot comply with government instruction. Hartlepool We have agreed [schools] will not reopen on Monday  June. Whilst we recognise the importance of schools reopening, we want to be absolutely clear that we will be taking a measured and cautious approach to this. We continue to work with schools to put in place appropriate measures to help keep children and staff safe when a phased reopening is possible.”

Virgin Atlantic plans to cut more than , jobs and shut its operations at Gatwick Airport. BA has announced plans to axe , posts – more than a quarter of its workforce – and senior BA cabin crew face a % pay cut under a proposed new contract. IAG, which owns British Airways, claims it does not expect demand for air travel to recover before , while Gatwick Airport has said it could take up to four years. But Mr Strutton told MPs: I believe that airlines are exaggerating the problem. The predictions that some of the airline leaders are saying, of up to a five or six-year recovery, is not in line with industry standard predictions.  Last week, the International Air Transport Association – which is usually the touchstone for these things – issued its new projections and said that by the end of  we would be back to  levels. Weaposre in a trough at the moment, we will be coming out of it over the next two-and-a-half years, and I think that airlines are egging the pudding too much to take advantage of the crisis to make changes and downsize their workforce unnecessarily. Unite union assistant general secretary Diana Holland told the committee she was extremely concerned about the industryaposs future. She said: If there isnapost revenue coming in to the industry itaposs not just the airlines , itaposs the airports, itaposs everything down the line and of course all the people that work there. We are extremely worried about the future, and thataposs why we need to come together now to look at what plan we have to restart, to rebuild confidence and to make sure that jobs, pay terms and conditions – while there maybe temporary changes as we reach that point – arenapost decimated for the future.” Ms Holland admitted there may be temporary changes to jobs, pay, terms and conditions, but stressed they must not be decimated for the future. Committee chairman Huw Merriman accused BA of an “opportunist an underhand approach to their workforce”. story: NewsCalls for urgent public inquiry into UK coronavirus response as death toll hits ,EXCLUSIVE: Top scientists and health professionals warn that lessons must be learned from the handling of the deadly disease before a second spike hits the UKShareCommentsByPippa CrerarDaily Mirror Political Editor:,  MAY NewsPM Boris Johnson addresses the nation about coronavirus " to FREE email alerts from Mirror - The Coronavirus BriefingSubscribeWhen you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. The experts branded the death toll in care homes a “scandal” and attacked the Government for failing to deal adequately with the first wave of Covid-. More than , people have signed a petition calling for an independent inquiry launched by campaign group March for Change. Ministers have not yet agreed to a public inquiry but have accepted that there will have to be a moment where they have to look back. At the No  briefing, Culture Secretary Oliver Dowden said: “Of course in any public health crisis there will be a time for lessons to be learned afterwards.” For the latest on the coronavirus pandemic, read our liveblog HERE. But Justice Secretary Robert Buckland added: “It would be very dficult now to judge what happened in March, bearing in mind the change in our knowledge.” Labour leader Keir Starmer has said it was “inevitable” there would be an official inquiry but the party has not yet called for one.However, it has demanded a probe into Covid- deaths in care homes, saying staff and residents had been tragically let down. Dr Kailash Chand, former deputy chair of the BMA Council, said: “The UK is a world-leader in the fields of science and healthcare, and our NHS is the envy of the world. “Despite this, we now have the highest number of deaths in Europe and the situation in our care homes is nothing short of a scandal. “Governments and media from across the globe, from Australia to Germany, are using the UK as an example of how not to tackle the crisis.  “It is time that we, the public, hold this government to account by demanding an urgent and independent public inquiry.” His concerns were echoed by Professor Dame Anne Glover, President of the Royal Society of Edinburgh who said: “More than  in  of coronavirus deaths worldwide have been in the UK. The UK government has struggled to deliver an effective response. “Faced with the potential of a second wave this winter, compounded with seasonal flu, we now need an urgent and independent public inquiry to ensure we all learn the lessons while we still have time to prepare.” Professor Martin McKee, professor of European Public Health at the London School of Hygiene and Tropical Medicine, added: “We clearly failed in the first wave and, with the possibility of a second wave come winter, we must make every effort to learn the lessons and be better prepared. “The public inquiry must be fast, independent and transparent to ensure we never again allow our NHS and care workers – and all key workers – to fight this battle without the adequate support and protection.”

You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailPunters could be stopped from drinking at the bar at pubs as part of new proposals aimed at helping hospitality firms reopen on July .Restrictions on the number of children in outdoor playing areas and patrols of smoking areas have also been put forward among potential measures touted to help sites meet coronavirus guidelines.Trade group UKHospitalityhas put forward the initial proposals alongside other industry leaders, in a -page draft document submitted to ministers.Earlier this month, Boris Johnson said that some hospitality firms could be able to reopen from July  at the earliest in the Governmentaposs third phase of the lockdown.For updates on coronavirus, follow our live blog HERE. Pubs, restaurants and hotels have remained closed since shutting their doors in March, with vast numbers of staff supported by the Governmentaposs furlough scheme. In the guidance, hospitality businesses claried that they do not wish to move ahead with reopening before the time is right and support a phased reopening approach. The proposals for restaurants suggest that condiments would not be left on tables, with inidually wrapped sauces and condiments handed out by staff on request. Meanwhile, the guidance suggests that restrictions on customers remaining at the bar after ordering and getting their drink should be considered.  It also proposed that customers are discouraged from ing empty glasses, customers are told to keep a safe distance away from bar staff and they will have to form a socially-distanced queue for orders. Tape on the floor showing the appropriate distance needed and customers collecting drinks from a pick up point are also among the measures suggested. Pubs will also have to put in place a plan for toilets to ensure they donapost become overcrowded.  Kate Nicholls, chief executive officer of UKH, said: UKH is working hard with our members and alongside other industry bodies to develop practical and effective guidelines to enable businesses to begin to reopen safely when the time is right. These are draft guidelines that have been shared with governments in England, Scotland and Wales, to help inform their thinking around reopening. We hope that the guidelines will help businesses draw up their own plans based on their premises, ensuring that safety is at the forefront of operations when the right time comes to reopen. It comes as pub bosses took advantage of a loophole in the easing of lockdown rules to serve scorched Brits as temperatures soared to C yesterday. Thirsty punters shared photos of themselves enjoying pints in disposable cups across social media on Wednesday as landlords re-opened their boozers for takeaways only. Bar staff were snapped bringing drinks outside in full PPE while one pub in Bournemouth saw huge snaking queues of delighted customers. This weekaposs mini-heatwave peaked yesterday - smashing the hottest day of the year record set on Tuesday - with many Brits more desperate than ever to enjoy a pint after weeks in lockdown.

Worryingly, more than two thirds who are experiencing anxiety said this was manesting itself in physical symptoms. Dr Meg Arroll, a chartered psychologist working with Healthspan, said: For a long time, young people have been thought to be most likely to suffer from an increase in stress and anxiety as they find their way in the world, or juggle young families and work. But while they are still spending a large part of their day feeling anxious, those over  have seen the biggest jump in the time they spend suffering from stress and anxiety in recent weeks. There is a real worry about peopleaposs mental health as they adapt to a new normal - particularly for older people who may see more changes than most in the way they live their lives in the coming months, leading to feelings of isolation, vulnerability and helplessness.  The study also found % of adults admitted they have times where they feel constantly worried or anxious. Financial worries are the biggest cause of stress, followed by health issues, a lack of sleep and weight gain. A loved oneaposs health issues and safety, work and the economy are also among the most common concerns. Three quarters of those polled have even lost sleep due to their anxiety - an average of four hours-a-week.Others have experienced physical symptoms as a result of their stress, including headaches or migraines , stomach discomfortand palpitations .A loss of appetite , a dwindling libidoand even dizzinessare also among the symptoms suffered when feeling stressed or anxious. Sufferers have also made a mistake at work , cancelled a night outor rowed with a friend or family member . But almost four in  admitted to turning to food and comfort eating when they feel under pressure. And more than one in  have called in sick to work, % have argued with a partner and one in twenty have even seen it end a relationship. Dr Sarah Brewer, author aposCBD: The Essential Guide to Health and Wellnessapos, said: Many people are trying to find natural ways to relieve stress with products like CBDworking really well to help reduce anxiety.  With people struggling to sleep we are also seeing a growth in self-care products such as Healthspanaposs Magnesium Bath Flakes and sleep aids such as Valerian and HTP. It also emerged half of those polled, via OnePoll, feel they are more prone to anxiety as they get older. And unsurprisingly, % are feeling more stressed about their health at the moment. Coronavirus is the top health concern currently for % , along with mental health , weightand fitness levels .More than half are also feeling anxious about things aposing to normalapos after the lockdown. Dr Meg Arroll added: Itaposs no surprise that the top three reasons for heightened levels of stress cited in this survey are financial concerns, health anxieties and a preoccupation with not getting enough sleep as these worries are often intertwined.  Therefore, breaking these negative thought cycles is important not only for mental health, but for overall physical health and ing also. With so much going on at the moment, it can feel like all we do is worry. This type of negative identity can be damaging over time as we ignore the other positive coping traits we have. To combat this there are exercises here that can help to build a more positive self-identity, which in turn will help you turn the volume down on anxiety. This is a great way to also engage in some self-kindness during Mental health Awareness Week. Top  causes of stress and anxiety. Financial worries. Health issues. Not getting enough sleep. Putting on weight. A family memberaposs health issues. Family safety. Work. The economy. Being late. Running out of time for something. Being in debt. Missing out on le experiences. Your diet. title: childrens hospice backed royal family
story: NewsChildrens hospice backed by royal family shuts after £million coronavirus lossesEXCLUSIVE Sophie, Countess of Wessex, patron of Shooting Star Children’s Hospices, has been left “incredibly saddened” after the coronavirus pandemic forced it to close one of its two sitesShareCommentsByRussell Myers:,  MAY Updated:,  MAY NewsSophie, Countess of Wessex, patron of Shooting Star Children’s Hospices " to FREE email alerts from Mirror - daily newsSubscribeWhen you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailA childrenaposs hospice backed by the Royal Family has been forced to close after Covid- blew a £million hole in its finances. Sophie, Countess of Wessex, patron of Shooting Star Children’s Hospices, has been left “incredibly saddened” after it shut one of two sites dedicated to helping  seriously ill kids. The charity, which has been visited by other senior royals including Prince Charles and Camilla, and the Duchess of Cambridge, offers emergency respite and end-of-le care. But a Mirror probe has discovered it is one of dozens of hospices, which rely on the public’s generosity, facing unprecedented hardship. Mass cancellations of fundraising events such as the London Marathon and the closure of high street charity shops have fuelled the crisis. Karen Sugarman, vice president of SSCH, which supports children in London and Surrey, said: “Covid- has had a devastating effect, like being run over by a massive steamroller. “Nobody could have been prepared for this. We are fighting with everything we have to be there for people who need us in their darkest hour.” Shooting Star was awarded £, in emergency government funding last month, but with services costing £, a day, Karen says it has “merely papered over the cracks”. She added: “The Government has been slow to react and there hasn’t been an adequate response.  “Sadly I don’t think we have ever been high enough on their agenda. “Charities around the world are suffering. We all have dferent needs but we are in this together.” The Mirror has been campaigning for the Government to double its funding to hospices to end the postcode lottery of hospice care, recruit more palliative care doctors and community nurses, and guarantee all terminally ill children receive end-of-le care. The closed facility, in Hampton, South West London, was visited by the Countess in February just weeks before the lockdown. Its ten child bedrooms and six family flats, normally full, will remain empty until funding is found.  To raise awareness carers recorded a version of Miley Cyrus’ song The Climb, complete with sign language, which the singer plugged on Twitter. A Buckingham Palace source said the Countess “is closely following their situation and being kept regularly informed”. They added: “She was incredibly moved by a video they posted recently and she was incredibly sad to hear that they have had to close the Hampton hospice for now. “She is hugely passionate about the role they play in the children’s lives and she will continue to support them where she can in the coming months.”  The hospice has also been supported by music mogul Simon Cowell and Spandau Ballet frontman Tony Hadley, plus David Walliams. But with the situation desperate, Karen, who has been with the charity  years, raised £, this month by singing and playing the accordion live to her friends. She said: “I don’t play the accordion and I’m not a great singer but we are all doing what we can. “The Countess and our other supporters are with us as well and that means so much. We are in an unprecedented times and must raise money to keep the service going for children and families who rely on us.”  She added: “We are extremely thankful for the rescue package but, for us and many others, this is merely papering over the cracks. “People assume we are funded by the NHS but... we are wholly reliant on the generosity of others.” Charles and Camilla officially opened the Hampton centre in , before Camilla invited some of the children to Clarence House to help decorate the Christmas tree. In , Kate – who is patron of East Anglia’s Children’s Hospices –also visited the charity at its former base in Middlesex.  As part of its emergency response to the pandemic, the Government promised £million in grants to support hospices. But insiders say it is not enough and the care and support needed by a quarter of a million people every year hangs in the balance. Pop star turned campaigner Hadley said: “We really rely on public and corporate donations, which sadly have decreased during the pandemic, as people face their own financial uncertainties. “I know this is a dficult time for many, but any money you can donate would be so appreciated.”

Aberdeenshire Council is considering making them capable of holding hundreds of coffins as part of measures to deal with the Covid-. The planning covers Scotlandaposs north east coast after local council bosses said cremation and burial services could be overwhelmed. Latest figures from National Records Scotland show that only  people have died in the region from coronavirus with , dying in Scotland. Philip McKay, head of roads, landscapes and waste services at the council, said at a virtual council meeting that initially the regionaposs funeral industry looked bleak from initial forecasts. Officials in New York City, US have already started stacking wooden coffins next to each other in deep trenches on Hart island. It comes after the city experienced more than , deaths from Covid- last month causing morgues across the city to become overwhelmed. Mr McKay said: As part of that modelling there were ideas similar to New Yorkaposs approach, that we may have to open what effectively would be strip lairs. The mass graves would be dug discreetly as officials added that it wouldnapost be appropriate to be done with members of the public present. Academics also suggested that mass graves could be introduceddeath and bereavement services are inundated with bodies from the Covid- crisis. The experts from the University of Huddersfield believed it would spark a major increase in mortality rates.  Coupled with staff absences, the researchers say that this would lead to struggles issuing death certicates, a bottleneck in funeral services and overfilled mortuaries. Dr Julia Meaton, Dr Anna Williams and researcher Helen-Marie Kruger, authors of the paper, said: The impact of such an increase from normal levels will mean that the authorities will struggle to maintain death registrations and disposals that will potentially have serious consequences. Practically, not being able to register a death or obtain a death certicate will mean that disposal cannot take place. The authors continued: There will be a bottleneck of burials and cremations, causing ceremonies to be delayed with mortuaries filled beyond capacity. Families will be prevented from closing bank accounts, pensions, selling property or receiving insurance, which could have financial implications. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailA great-grandad has celebrated his th birthday more than three decades after a heart transplant. Eddie Tierney was  when he had the op in  – and surgeons warned him the organ may last only five years. But  years later he is still going strong and yesterday welcomed a new law which means everyone in England is assumed to be an organ donor, unless they opt out. Max and Keira’s Law is named after Max Johnson, , of Winsford, Cheshire, and his heart donor Keira Ball, nine, who died in a car accident near her home in Barnstaple, Devon, in . The Mirror campaigned for four years to bring it to the statute book. Eddie lives in Wales, where the opt-out system has been in place since . “It is a good idea as far I’m concerned,” said Eddie, who lives with his we Phyllis, , near Rhyl, Denbighshire. “It means there is more chance of people getting a heart transplant than there was when I had mine.” Eddie, a former cabinet maker who later ran a second-hand shop, fell ill with a flu virus which attacked his heart. “I went in with the flu and the next thing I was told I had six weeks to live,” he said.  After a spell in Glan Clwyd Hospital in nearby Bodelwyddan he received a transplant at Harefield Hospital in West London. The operation was performed by world famous surgeon Sir Magdi Yacoub. Eddie said: “I was his rd heart ­transplant at Harefield. He told me when I had it done that I should get five years.” One of the young doctors who cared for him initially in North Wales later became the Tierney family’s local GP. Dr David Whyler phoned Eddie last week to say happy birthday. Eddie said: “He told me he could never believe that I would get to . I’m still here. To be still here  years on, it’s just remarkable. I just can’t believe it.” Eddie later discovered his heart donor was a -year-old woman. And although he never met her family, he said: “I’m so grateful to them.” He still enjoys road trips on his two motorcycles and added: “I’m looking forward to getting out on my bike when the lockdown ends.” Eddie, who has a son, Michael, a daughter, Debbie, four grandchildren and a three-month-old great-grandson, Caleb, had to scrap a birthday party planned last Friday.

You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailThere was little doubt of our hunger toto normality as cars queued outside McDonald’s drive-throughs hours before they reopened today. And as fast-food fans grabbed meals to go, there were plenty of other indicators that the country is getting back on the move... McDonaldaposs Burgers were back on the menu as McDonald’s pulled up the shutters at  drive-throughs across the South East. Despite the sites offering a limited menu, cars were bumper-to-bumper before opening time at am in queues not seen since the Boxing Day sales. Follow our live blog for the latest coronavirus news and updates The chain capped orders to £ per car and said it will close sitesthey became over-congested. McDonald’s said: “McDonald’s and its franchisees are working closely with local authorities and the police, and may determine it is necessary to close lanesqueues cause disruption at busier sites or put employees or customers at risk.” The giant aims to have all of its drive-throughs open by early June. Buses Bus operators First Bus, Stagecoach and Arriva have added extra services after limiting passenger numbers to % of capacity to help ensure social distancing.  First Bus said drivers will do a head count using a device on ticket machines, closing doors and setting off when % capacity is reached. Passengers who make it on will be asked to sit a safe distance apart. Dave Lynch, of parent company FirstGroup, said: “We have been working round the clock to find ways to innovate so we can ensure safe, socially distanced space.” Stagecoach and Arriva want commuters to wear masks and sit by a window on their own unless with a family member – and keep seats in front and behind free. Passengers paying with cash must have the exact fare, as drivers will not give change to reduce the risk of infection. The Confederation of Passenger Transport said it was keeping people up to date “on how they can play their part to keep the bus network safe”.  A Transport Focus poll revealed % would not travel unless social distancing was in place – up from % two weeks ago. And % would not be happy to use public transport unless passengers had to wear face masks – up from %. Shops Poundland re-opened  stores yesterday, taking the total trading to  this week. Furniture Village has re-opened six sites while the remaining  will be ready for trading on Saturday. And John Lewis has outlined plans to get ready for shoppers as it anticipates a green light. Perspex screens have been fitted at checkouts and information desks. Stores with large car parks are likely to open first and private buses may ferry staff to workpublic transport is an issue.  Clothes tried on but not bought will be quarantined before ing to rails and floors will get m spacing stickers.But the firm may have to halt consultations on baby goods, fashion and technology until social distancing is axed.Operations chief Andrew Murphy said: “We want to be safe – not fast.” Pubs Pubs bolstered their case to reopen on July  with new proposals to satisfy the Government that they can safely serve food and drink. Trade body UK Hospitality said plans include no drinking at the bar, no salt and pepper or sauces on tables, and cutlery brought to diners with their food in table service only.  Roped off areas, restrictions on kids’ playgrounds and patrolled smoking areas are also on the cards. UKH chief Kate Nicholls said the draft guidelines have been shared with governments in England, Scotland and Wales. She added: “We hope the guidelines will help businesses draw up plans based on their premises, ensuring safety is at the forefront when the right time comes to reopen.”  Kick-off pm Sat... on the telly Football fans without Sky or BT Sport could be able to watch live matches for free at pm on Saturdays, Culture Secretary Oliver Dowden suggested. Broadcasters have previously been banned from screening fixtures at that time amid fears fans would watch on TV rather than attend games. But matches are due to take place behind closed doors when the season resumes. Mr Dowden said: “I think that creates an opportunity for us to be able to get some sport, some Premier League, free-to-air.” He added: “Those discussions are ongoing.”  Mr Dowden also offered hope for UK staycations, saying he’d “love to get the tourism sector up as quickly as we possibly can”. Mayorsapos plea for homeless Mayors have urged the Government to seize a “once in a generation” chance to tackle rough sleeping after the crisis. Labour leaders in Manchester, Liverpool, London, Sheffield and North Tyne want ministers to deliver a new funding package. During the pandemic more than , rough sleepers have been offered emergency digs.  But the initial funding package is due to run out within weeks and ministers say getting them in longer-term accommodation is up to skint local authorities. Councils say extra funding to tackle Covid- is too little. Labour leader Keir Starmer backed a joint statement by the mayors, which said: “When this crisis is over, we cannotto business as usual.” Boris boosts gongs hope Boris Johnson has given the clearest hint yet that he will back a medal for our NHS heroes. The PM said this year’s June honours announcement will be delayed to autumn so it can recognise the contribution of those fighting Covid-. In a written statement to Parliament, he said: “The Government is clear there will be opportunities to mark the contributions of so many – but at the appropriate time.” It was the latest boost for the Mirror’s Give NHS Heroes a Medal campaign and came after Captain Tom Moore, , was given a knighthood for raising £million for the NHS. Brits looking at holidays abroad as restrictions lt Bookings for holidays to countries that have lted travel restrictions spiked this week, in a sign the nation is getting back on its feet. Portugal and Greece have eased their lockdowns and Spain plans to end its own next month. Experts believe millions of Brits are banking on a September getaway. Hays Travel co-founder Irene Hays said: “At the moment they are booking for September. Without a doubt, the British people are ready for a holiday.”

title: nations favourite sandwich been named
story: NewsNations favourite sandwich has been confirmed - and its a bacon buttyA poll of , adults were asked what their favourite sarnies with a bacon butty beating cheese and pickle, beef and horseradish, and chicken and bacon to the top spotShareCommentsByLorraine King:,  MAY Updated:,  MAY NewsThe nations favourite sandwich is a bacon butty " to FREE email alerts from Mirror - daily newsSubscribeWhen you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. Sometimes they’ll include recommendations for other related newsletters or services we offer. OurPrivacy Noticeexplains more about how we use your data, and your rights. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailThe bacon butty has been named the nationaposs best loved sandwich - with egg and cress sneaking into the top ten. A poll of , adults saw the British staple of fried or grilled bacon sandwiched between two chunky slices of bread come out on top. Other popular fillings include cheese and pickle, chicken and bacon, and even a filling of crisps. The results show a sht in tastes, with a similar study from  seeing a plain cheese sandwich top the chart. This was followed by ham and cheese - which has now slipped to sixth place - with the nation favouring sausage, and egg mayonnaise two years on.  It also emerged that when it comes to preparing the perfect sandwich, aposwhite, medium sliced bread with the crusts left on and cut into squaresapos, is the top choice. A spokesman for Warburtons, which commissioned the  and  studies, said: However you prepare it, or whatever you fill it with, thereaposs something that canapost be beaten about a good old British sandwich. Itaposs interesting to see bacon top the list as weaposre all craving comforting, simple and hearty meals as social distancing continues. Itaposs also great to see Brits get more creative in the kitchen with jam and cheese, and even peanut butter and marmalade being used in the nationaposs sandwiches.  The combinations are endless so it comes as no surprise that bread is still one of the nationaposs favourite go-tos. The study also found itaposs not just sandwiches being enjoyed more by the nation, as a third of adults are eating more toasties now than they did before the lockdown, with cheese the most popular filling. And among the best loved condiments to enjoy with sandwiches were pickle , ketchupand mayonnaise . Others choose to spice up their sarnie with a splash of sriracha , a drop of tabascoor a spread of English mustard .  It also emerged almost half of those polled are eating more bread, while a third are enjoying more toast since the start of lockdown. The average person will enjoy four sandwiches and two toasties during a typical week - but a fth are currently tucking into more than seven sandwiches in a seven-day period. As a result, the average household is getting through two loaves of bread a week - with a quarter consuming more than three loaves in that time. Nearly a third Brits said the reason theyaposve had more bread is because they arenapost buying as many meals away from home, and  per cent put it down to having lots of other food in the house which goes well with it. Lunch is still the most popular time to enjoy a sarnie or toastie with  per cent doing so, while a quarter of Brits frequently indulge by snacking on a sandwich.  More than a third actually prefer sandwiches for lunch over a hot meal, and  per cent would even struggle to go a day without enjoying a slice of bread. However, people are no longer creatures of habit as  per cent of those polled, via OnePoll, try to alternate their sandwich fillings, and one in  have been more experimental with fillings during lockdown. Some of the strange and unusual creations put together by the UK were also revealed with one respondent admitting to enjoying a chocolate spread and salami sandwich. Another confessed to eating a chocolate biscuit sandwich, with corned beef and peanut butter also among the inventive combinations.

story: NewsStudent, , spent eight days on a ventilator after mistaking coronavirus for fatigueLucy Patterson felt short of breath after doing squats during a Joe Wicks workout at her student home in Liverpool, but collapsed days later after developing pneumonia in % of her lungsShareCommentsBySophie Donovan:,  MAY NewsLucy Patterson initially thought she was exhausted from doing squats " to FREE email alerts from Mirror - The Coronavirus BriefingSubscribeWhen you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailA -year-old student spent eight days on a ventilator after she mistook Covid- for fatigue from doing too many squats. Zoology student Lucy Patterson began feeling short of breath after a home workout, but put it down to the intense exercise. The University of Liverpool undergraduate had no underlying health conditions and thought she was low risk. But after collapsing eight days later on April , she called her GP who told her to call an ambulance. Lucy had developed pneumonia in % of her lungs and spent eight days on a ventilator at Liverpool University Hospital. The student from Ballymoney, Northern Ireland, revealed her story to student news site The Tab. She said: It just felt like my lungs were tiny. It felt like I was really conscious of the amount of oxygen I was getting in and breathing out. I initially thought, aposoh, this has been a really tough workout, Iaposve overdone it, Iaposve overdone the squats.apos Like most people doing lockdown, Iaposve been so bored that Iaposve just done exercise every day - before, I was a bit more sporadic. Theyaposd been going fine and I was really enjoying them. It was only when the shortness of breath started that I realised something was wrong, because it was the exact same workout that had been fine every day before.  But it took me hours of lying down on the sofa before I was fit enough to go upstairs again. It started feeling like I was a bit more out of breath doing things, so I didnapost take it to be that serious - I just thought maybe I was having a slow day. But as the days went on, it just felt like my lungs got smaller and smaller. Lucy had stayed with her housemates in Smithson, Liverpool to avoid spreading the virus to her parents back home. She had to tell her parents Helen Patterson,  and Michael Patterson, , about the seriousness of her condition over Facetime. She said: Before I was also in the aposuni canapost be over yetapos mentality and wanted to stay on with my flatmates and try and make lockdown fun - ironic.  It must have been very scary for my parents - I called them pretty much every day and they were just getting snippets of how I was progressing, whereas I was seeing it continuously. They saw me deteriorating with every call. I was so blase about it, so my family were much more concerned about me than I was. Lucy spent eight days on a ventilator, but admitted it wasnapost as scary as she had imagined. She now regrets not going to hospital sooner. I was definitely a part of that group before that was really blase about it. I do a science subject, so Iaposd seen the statistics for young people.  I was like, aposthe likelihood of me getting this, let alone it affecting me in any way is so small - I donapost need to worry.apos But when youaposre lying in that hospital bed, you donapost knowyouaposre going to be that .% thataposs going to be unlucky. I wasnapost improving for about five days, so it could have gone the other way for me. Everyone deserves help - just because someone is worse off than you, doesnapost mean that you need to save a hospital bed. If youaposre sick, youaposre helping the doctors more by going in early and getting checked, rather than trying to wait it out in your bed and then getting to the point youaposre so sick an ambulance has to come pick you up.

You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid Email VE Day celebrations could have led to a sudden spike in a cityaposs coronavirus cases, a medical expert said today.And it is feared the same could happen at the end of Ramadan this weekend following an increase in fresh infections in Bradford. Prof John Wright, head of the Bradford Institute for Health Research at Bradford Royal Infirmary , said there were  new cases six days after the VE Day anniversary on May . Up until that point, the number of cases at the hospital had been reducing, with only three reported on Monday May . But three days later, on Thursday May , the number of cases shot up to  - a figure Prof Wright suspects has come from VE parties that ended in fist fights or embraces. For the latest on the coronavirus pandemic, click here   Writing in a diary for the BBC, the professor said: Itaposs just one figure, and in normal times we might discount it as random iation. However these are times of alertness, and every flicker of the Covid dashboard needle triggers nervous anticipation of a possible spike. There is a delay between infection and symptoms, usually about five-to-seven days.  So these cases would have been incubating since the week before - and possibly since the communal gatherings on VE Day, six days earlier. VE Day - the th anniversary of the Allied victory in Europe in World War Two - would have been marked in a huge way at any other time. But in this current climate, communities did what they could within lockdown limitations. Although staff at the AE department at BRI were acutely aware of a lack of care in social distancing as they dealt with many assault cases involving alcohol that night. AE consultant David Greenhorn said: Itaposs not possible to punch someone from m away.

Shilpa Sethi, , from New Delhi, India, had always wanted a curvy body, so decided to start saving up k for a ‘Brazilian Butt Lt’.The model, who has over . million followers on her Instagram page where she posts X-rated pictures of herself in lingerie, said: I have always admired a curvy body. And I was very flat, at first.She added that despite her mum not wanting her to have the procedure, she went ahead with it anyway. But things did not go according to plan. Shilpa explained: I chose my doctor based on what I later discovered to be fake reviews. That first surgery was botched, and I had complications immediately after the procedure. I was short of breath, and felt a sharp pain in my leg. Unable to contact the Miami-based doctor directly, Shilpa did a little investigating and uncovered a culture of deception in the cosmetic surgery trade. His office staff members had bribed every patient in the office with free [pain relieving] Arnica cream for their fake review. The only reason I’m telling my story now is because I don’t want anybody  to go through what Iaposve been through. I wish I had never picked him as my first doctor. Shilpa is furious with the people who had written the  testimony. She said: People don’t care about other people as long as they get what they want from writing their fake review.  The end result of that surgery was not only a lopsided rear end, but considerable discomfort. It was very painful, and I wasn’t able to sit on my butt for four months. Now, following three more expensive and aposaggressively painfulapos corrective procedures costing a total of k – for which she travelled to Colombia twice and had to undergo a aposJ-plasmaapos to reattach loose skin back onto her muscles – Shilpa is finally able put this painful experience behind her. She also decided to treat herself to breast augmentation in the final cosmetic procedure. The model, who makes thousands of dollars a month from OnlyFans alone, said: It’s paid for itself now, put it that way.

The unnamed Russian woman was working on a Covid- ward, treating only male patients, a a hospital in Tula. The image quickly went viral, as she can be seen wearing matching black bra and knickers as she writes a patientaposs chart. But hospital chiefs were not amused and punished the nurse for “non-compliance with the requirements for medical clothing”. The nurse, in her s said she was “too hot” wearing her nurses’ unorm under the gown.She told her managers at Tula Regional Clinical Hospital that she did not realise the PPE she wore when treating coronavirus patients was so transparent.The regional health ministry reported that “a disciplinary sanction was applied to the nurse of the infectious diseases department who violatedrequirements”. Her chiefs at first said the woman was wearing “lingerie” but later claimed she had a “swimming suit” beneath the gown. The nurse has not spoken publicly on the incident and the exact details of the disciplinary action were not revealed. One patient said there was no objection from men in the coronavirus ward while admitting there was some embarrassment. A reader of local newspaper Tula News congratulated the nurse. “At least someone has a sense of humour in this gloomy, gloomy reality,” said Sergey Ratnikov. “Why the reprimand ” asked Albert Kuzminov. Another supporter said: “Everyone shouted at her, but no one paid attention that she was dressed in this way because of the heat. “Maybe you need to yell at the management … because there is no normal air conditioning here.” Marina Astakhova posted: Well done, she raised the mood of the patients.” While Valery Kapnin wrote: “Why punish the nurse, you need to reward her. “Seeing this outfit, no-one wants to die.”

You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid Email Thousands of visitors have packed into a theme park in Wuhan after it was allowed to reopen following the coronavirus outbreak.The Happy Valley attraction has been shut for four months after the city - which has a population of  million - was put on lockdown. The killer virus, which has claimed more than , lives around the world, is believed to have originated in a wet market in Wuhan late last year. But the Chinese government claims huge strides have been made in battling the disease, and le is slowly going back to normal in the epicentre. Yesterday the theme park, which was founded in , welcomed , people as it threw open its gates - in spite of fears that China could be set for a second wave of infections. For the latest on the coronavirus pandemic, click here  It is now allowed to operate at % of its previous capacity. People have to book in advance and have their temperatures taken before they enter. It comes after authorities in Wuhan said they have already screened more than half of its population - including doing half a million tests in a single day this week. Figures released by the Wuhan Health Commission yesterday showed that , nucleic acid tests had been carried out the previous day. Just  new cases - of people who were not showing symptoms - were identied. The city is aiming to have tested every person by May . Described as a apos-day battleapos, the mass testing initiative started on May  - with the central municipal government ordering all  of its districts to come up with their own way to test every resident within its borders. Parks and public squares are being used as assembly points and makesht swabbing stations. Each Covid- test takes about three minutes, while the procedure is free to the public, officials said.  Health officials in Hubei Province in Central China say more than half of Wuhanaposs population has been tested so far, though, according to local media reports, some three million residents had also been tested during lockdown. While it is not mandatory for members of the public to take part in the testing campaign, officials have described it as a responsibility.  The tests are mainly targeting the elderly and children, who would not have been tested in large numbers during lockdown. Wuhan officials believe mass testing is the only way to ensure the safe reopening of schools and businesses. title: dundee united ian harkes grandfather coronavirus
story: He could hardly have been further away, but the coronavirus pandemic hit close to home for Dundee United midfielder Ian Harkes.His grandfather, Ron Kunihiro, had been fighting Covid- since early March with Harkes stuck in Dundee unable to catch a flight back to America.Thankfully, now at their family home in Virginia and by his side, Harkes has witnessed the -year-old recover.“I was just happy to get home. My granddad got out of the hospital and he’s been battling Covid,” the -year-old said.“He’s had it for a while. It’s been a long process which started back in the beginning of March when he first started to feel ill.“He went in to the hospital for  days or so. I was still in Dundee so we had to FaceTime or Zoom call the family to keep updated on everything.“Thankfully, we were able to find some flights and get back over.“He’s healthy now which is great. It’s been great to see him recover and nice to be here with the family.“The challenge now is getting back over to Scotland but, thankfully, I’ve got a UK passport so I should be OK!”Harkes travelled back to the states with fiancée and Celtic Women’s player Sarah Teegarden a few weeks back.Their wedding plans are on hold and the country is in disarray but Harkes insists it’s nice to spend precious time with his loved ones.He continued: “She was able to come back as well which is good.“It’s nice to spend time together but all our wedding plans will be pushed back now.“On the mental side being back with them all helps tremendously, missing them throughout the year.“They came over around Christmas time but seeing them again six months later has been big. It always gives me a lt.“It’s a bit dferent here than the UK. Some things don’t seem so shut down but that’s just America right now – we’re not quite sure what’s going on.“It’s quite crazy just now with the amount of cases and, unfortunately, the amount of deaths we’ve had in America.“I think the country’s a little bit all over the place, some places are opening up and some are closed, but right now we’re still in lockdown in Virginia.“All the states are dferent but it’s been OK here.“I’m not sure how long that will be but we need to be safe, especially with having that experience in my family.“I think we’ve all had a little bit of a dferent view towards it but we’ll see how it goes and hope for the best.“We can still exercise and things like that. I’ve had space to go and run and cycle, do some things in the yard and touch a ball every day.“It’s been good to have certain resources back home and to keep doing stuff.”Like most, lockdown has been a test for Harkes’ mentally and physically. For him, it’s a challenge he soon hopes to rise to on the pitch.Harkes added: “It’s definitely been a challenge on both sides but, thankfully, the club provided us with a great fitness programme before we went on furlough to keep us ticking over.“I’ve been active and all of us want to be flying when we finally get the go-ahead to get back to playing.“We’re all trying to push each other and push ourselves.“On the mental side, the way we ended was a little tough because we wanted to play for the fans and finish out the season.“We really felt like we deserved the title and we knew it then but we just wanted to finish off the games and prove it to everyone.“We’ll have that desire to get back on the pitch and play hard when we finally get it going.”The United support have taken to Harkes since he joined the club in January last year, as much for his flowing locks as his skill on the pitch.He is pleased to inform them nothing has changed on the hair front in lockdown but that he might soon be forced to take matters into his own hands.“I’m still going strong but it will be cut before everything gets going again,” Harkes said.“I think it’s getting a bit ridiculous now.“I don’t want to start putting it up in a bun and everything. title: lee wilkie i am all for reconstruction but now is not the time
story: I’ve been hugely in favour of league reconstruction for a long time. However, I’m getting the sneaking feeling now just isn’t the right time.That might come as a surprise to people who have read this column over the past few weeks andIt seems like we are slowly moving toward the game eventually restarting.Yesterday’s announcement of the Premiership being called with Celtic champions and Hearts relegated came as no surprise.There was no other credible option.The Jambos will, obviously, feel aggrieved and so will some Rangers fans but it is the right call.I said from the start of the shutdown that reconstruction is the only way to ensure no club is unduly affected by leagues ending early.And I still stand by that.However, the situation we are in now a couple of months down the line leads me to pause for thought.Clubs are in such dire straits right now, nobody really knows how many might go to the wall before the game restarts.If we’ve already agreed reconstruction and, say, five clubs go under, we have to start the whole process over again.The decision-makers in the game have shown over the past few farcical weeks that there’s a realI can see where the Premiership clubs were coming from when they canned the revamp talks  days ago.It looks like a mammoth job to get football back on the pitch sometime soon, eventhe SPFL are planning to restart again in July.With that in mind, I’d prefer reconstruction talks were put on the back burner – not binned, by any means – and talked about in a measured fashion over the next few months.Start the new season as normal – eventhings have to wait a few weeks to get the green light – and then get a plan in place for the season after.That way, the new set-up comes from a foundation of stability rather than the uncertainty the game is surrounded by right now and what the future might hold.At the very least, clubs can now plan for the season ahead, knowing who they will be facing eventhere are still doubts around.The big thing for all clubs is getting that stability back, that certainty to then plan ahead.It feels like that’s coming – once it’s back, start talking reconstruction to improve our game in the long-term.I felt for a couple of my old team-mates who were released by their clubs over the weekend.The coronavirus pandemic is obviously a dficult time for everybody but being without a job through it is horrible.Particularly when there’s no prospect right now of finding another employer.With football clubs unable to make moves in the transfer market because of the shutdown, that leaves players like Danny Swanson and Craig Conway in limbo.Normally, I’d expect them to have plenty of offers to think over this summer.Swansonis one of the most talented players I’ve ever seen in training.He was superb at Tannadice.He obviously hasn’t played so much at St Johnstone for whatever reason, leading to his departure.Conway, meanwhile, has had a really successful career since leaving United.He was always such a fit guy and a great lad to have in the dressing-room, he’d normally find a new club no problem.Right now, though, nobody knows what will happen.I was pleased to see Dundee say they were extending some contracts.Christie Elliott’s for another year, a clause he had in his deal, and Paul McGowan, Josh Meekings and Tom Field till July. Even though that’s just a few weeks, it sends the right message – that they are going to look after players.I don’t imagine every club will be doing that.A lot of players will have a stressful summer coming up with no club able to sign them.Theof football with the Bundesliga starting at the weekend was very much a step in the right direction for me.It might have been a bit strange without the crowds but needs must. It’s a bit of light at the end of a long tunnel.For as little as £. a month you can access all of our content, including Premium articles.
