reopen from Tuesday, May , but by appointment only.The booking system is to help comply with social distancing regulations, protecting residents and staff.Residents will be able to book an appointment from am on Thursday, May  via the Vale councilrsquos website.There will be  slots released for the next fortnight of bookings, beginning May  -  slots at Atlantic Trading Estate and  for Llandow.Any resident undertaking a journey to a HWRC within the Vale must comply with the current Government guidance and adhere to the social distancing measures that are in place to ensure safe operation and use of the centres.To begin with, only cars will be permitted access to the HWRC on Atlantic Trading Estate, Barry, and at Llandow.It will not be possible to provide access or appointment for trailers or vans at this time.Due to current demand, initially the council will be only be issuing one appointment slot per household, per month until further notice.Residents are asked to only make a bookingit is absolutely necessary, due to the sitesrsquo reduced capacity, and to arrive no earlier than five minutes before their allocated time to avoid any unnecessary queuing.The guidelines state that before visiting, residents must sort their waste or recycling appropriately to minimise the time at the site and residents must provide proof of residency eg driving licence or utility bill and display this in their windscreen while waiting to enter the site.Residents must follow on-site safety signs and guidance and residents should only exit their car when advised to do so by a member of site staff.Staff will be unable to provide assistance with lting or sorting so it is important to ensure all waste and recycling is manageable.Residents are also reminded thatthey do not respect social distancing or are abusive to staff they will be asked to leave site.It is important to remember that fly-tipping is a crime and leaving items outside the gates of a HWRC, on the street or in parks, woodlands and fields may result in a fixed penalty notice of up to pound being issued or even prosecution.Vale council cabinet member for neighbourhood services and transport, Cllr Peter King said: ldquoIrsquod like to thank residents for the assistance they have provided by storing items they wish to dispose of until now.ldquoUnfortunately, the period during which our household waste recycling centres were closed means there is now a backlog to clear, which is why we need a strict booking system until demand s to normal.ldquoWe appreciate this may cause some inconvenience but would ask residents for their patience at this time. article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey been sitting in a bag unused for eight weeks and I was getting far too used to sitting in my pyjamas all day.ldquoThe aim was to capture this strange moment in history and to be able to do what I love - get out and take photographs while following government guidelines.ldquoI havenrsquot been able to work since March and photography is a huge part of my lestyle and happiness.ldquoI have been able to create beautul memories for these families.ldquoBack in March our family adopted a beautul family cat, Rocky, from Annarsquos Rescue Centre in Rumney, she said. ldquoWe were amazed to discover how combining my doorstep photography project as a fundraiser."Donations were not compulsory.ldquoDuring lockdown this money is very much needed to feed the surplus cats that currently canrsquot be those who took part.Miss Dimech and her partner allowed  minutes for each household.ldquoIt was amazing to meet so many new faces and to catch up with some of my previous clients," she said. ldquoEach title: welsh government resilience plan supports education over s
story: The plan helps ensure that learners are supported throughout the coronavirus pandemic.It is aimed at education for learners aged  and over, including further and higher education, apprenticeships, employability and adult learning.The plan identies the priority groups most in need of support and sets out the expectations of how education providers and the Welsh Government will work together in response to covid- and how key decisions will be communicated.Since education providers in Wales closed for face-to-face learning on March , colleges and universities have moved to remote learning, delivering online lectures, tutorials and reviews, as well as ensuring support for more vulnerable learners continues.The plan is ided into three phases ndash the current lsquorescuersquo phase is focused on ensuring education providers have immediate security of funding and arrangements for learning in place this academic year the lsquoreviewrsquo phase plans for potential changes this autumn and the lsquorenewrsquo phase will put arrangements in place for the remainder of the academic year -.The plan identies learners for whom the coronavirus is likely to cause the most disruption, including Year  and , and vocational learners who need to access colleges or workplaces to complete their courses.The Welsh Government has increased online resources for post- through its Hwb , with distance learning resources available for both learners and providers.The Resilience Plan follows the publication of the continuity of learning plan for schools, lsquoStay Safe. Stay Learningrsquo, published last month.Education minister Kirsty Williams has also announced that pound.m of capital funding, part of the Secircr Cymru programme, will be used to invite applications from Welsh universities to submit novel research proposals that could contribute to or boost the advancement of research that impacts covid-.Ms Williams said: ldquoThe coronavirus has presented huge challenges for both students and education providers, in both the immediate and the longer term.ldquoThis Resilience Plan will provide a clear focus so we can work together with our education partners to overcome these challengesldquoThis plan will complement our continuity of learning plan for schools, lsquoStay Safe. Stay Learningrsquo, but recognises the greater levels of autonomy and ersity of education and training provided by the post- sector.ldquoOur colleges, universities and training providers are critical to the national response to the coronavirus and the rebuilding of the economy. We are committed to doing all we can to support them.Minister for economy, transport and North Wales, Ken Skates said: ldquoWe do not only want to bounce back from this pandemic, but to build back better by creating a national economy which sees employment, wealth and prosperity sp equally across Wales.ldquoThe post- education sector will be crucial to this.ldquoAs we shape our recovery from the impacts of coronavirus, we are committed to doing all we can to provide a strong foundation for those looking for employment, learners, trainees and apprentices to flourish in the future.ldquoThis incredibly challenging period has already highlighted the talent, commitment and incredible resilience of training and learning providers in supporting iniduals here in Wales.ldquoItrsquos efforts like these that will help ensure we emerge from this crisis stronger than ever. article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey site"+site_id+"url"+article_url+"cid"+content_id+"random"+.getTime+try  __Show catch console.log -- s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"commentSorry, an error occurred.Sign in or register leave a comment or rate a comment -- []sw.documents.asynctruestext javascripts.src+static++.plista async++.jsg  --Most readCommented"Loading...Read more Get involved with the news in your communitySend your stories and photos now--       ByThis website and associated newspapers adhere to the Independent Press Standards Organisations Editors Code of Practice. title: south east london tower block blaze brought control
story: The brigade said  fire engines and around  firefighters were called to the scene on Childers Street, Deptford.A flat on the top floor of a six-storey block and the roof were alight, leading two people to leave the flat and forcing firefighters to evacuate the rest of the block. vw, px"The blaze broke out on Wednesday evening There were no reports of injuries, Station Commander Emma Carr said.ldquoTwo people left the affected flat and firefighters evacuated the rest of the block as a precaution due to the amount of smoke.ldquoThis was a challenging incident due to the fire being in a roof hatch and firefighters worked hard to bring it under control.ldquoAerial ladder s were used to tackle the blaze in the roof from height.The flat blaze in #Deptford is now under control. Crews will remain on scene throughout the night damping down. There are no reports of any injuries https:t.co QUWjsYuJ pic IsqXgBFpmdash London Fire BrigadeMay , Earlier, plumes of smoke were seen billowing from the tower block.Firefighters were alerted at .pm and  calls were made to the control room.Local resident Agnes Agyepong said: ldquoI turned the corner towards Childers Street and saw residents and bystanders standing out on the street.ldquoWhen I looked up I saw the top of the block of flats engulfed in flames.ldquoThick black smoke was coming out as well.ldquoChildren were witnessing this.ldquoAshes were blowing in the street.Ms Agyepong said: ldquoThe mood was very sombrehellip people could not believe that they are on lockdown, and now this has happened on top of everything .Fire crews from the south London districts of Deptford, New Cross, Greenwich, Old Kent Road, Lewisham and surrounding fire stations assisted at the scene..push,i[r].l*new Dateas,ms[]a.asynca.srcgmgagagagagagagagagagaga, title: South-east London tower-block blaze brought under control article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey site"+site_id+"url"+article_url+"cid"+content_id+"random"+.getTime+try  __Show catch console.log -- s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"commentSorry, an error occurred.Sign in or register leave a comment or rate a comment -- []sw.documents.asynctruestext javascripts.src+static++.plista async++.jsg  --Most readCommented"Loading...Read more Get involved with the news in your communitySend your stories and photos now--       ByThis website and associated newspapers adhere to the Independent Press Standards Organisations Editors Code of Practice. title: experts say schools reopening
story: While experts agree that children tend to get coronavirus less severely than adults, little is known about how infectious they are.Scientists also agree that testing and tracing is vital in order to further ease lockdown restrictions.But what do they say about the safety of opening schools ndash What are the risks Mark Woolhouse, professor of Infectious Disease Epidemiology, University of Edinburgh, told the PA news agency there are three main risks associated with children ing to school.He described these as the risk to children, the risk to teachers, and the risk of transmission in the community increasing.Speaking as an independent researcher, and not in an advisory role, he said: ldquoCovid-, though a very unpleasant virus, and capable of causing illness, on occasion in any age group, in fact, is very, very very rarely a serious problem in children.ldquoStaff are of course adults so they are more vulnerable to infection, more vulnerable to symptomatic infection.But he added that how vulnerable teachers are in school depends on whether they are considered a major source of outbreaks.ldquoAnd so far, the indications from around the world are they are not, said Prof Woolhouse.Prof Woolhouse said he knows of no evidence that suggests school staff are at greater risk in the workplace that any other adult in a workplace. vw,vw,px, px"ndash Will allowing some children toto school increase community transmission Prof Woolhouse said it is ldquodefinitely a possibility that opening schools may cause the R rate to increase in the community.This refers to how many people on average an infected person is likely to pass coronavirus on to.He explained: ldquoI think the bottom line is until wersquove sorted out this business of whether children do pass on the virus or not, we canrsquot be sure how much R will go up, but itrsquos possible, it goes up by a lot less than we currently think.Michael Tildesley is an associate professor at Warwick University who sits on a  within the Scientic Advisory Group for Emergencies , and is modelling the effect opening schools will have.He said: ldquoCautiously, I think wersquore in a position where we can start to think about opening schools in the next few weeks.ldquoBut these relaxations need to be done gradually, you need to be monitoring it andnecessary prepare to reinstate lockdown measures, including school closureswe do start to see cases rising.ndash What effect will social distancing have in schools Dr Tildesley saidschool reopenings need to happen with social-distancing measures in place where possible, eventhe children are not transmitting Covid-.He explained: ldquoThe very fact that theyrsquore mixing, slightly raises the risk to say teachers, for instance.ldquoI think, overall, probably the risk to the average teacher of mixing with children is low, but I think wersquore in a situation at the moment where I would never go and advise in the current climate that we shouldnrsquot put social-distancing measures in place as wersquore reopening.Dr Lucy Wenham, lecturer of education at the University of Bristol, said the measures may prove dficult to enforce with very young children, and could also also be traumatic.She told PA: ldquoI donrsquot want to say, itrsquos child abuse, but it seems itrsquos a very, itrsquos a traumatic thing to put children through.Dr Wenham said there was no guarantee the young children would be ing to the same teacher, adding: ldquoSo, they wonrsquot even be going back to a known teacher so I think itrsquos usually harrowing, and thatrsquos a bizarre to want to do.ldquoMental health has to come first. Theyrsquore not going to read or theyrsquore not going to learn anythingtheyrsquore traumatised by being in a very unusual situation. vw,vw,px, px"Staff at the Coastline fish and chip shop and ice cream parlour on Blyth beach, Northumberland wearing PPE ndash Should school staff be given Personal Protective Equipment  Dr Tildesley said it might make a dference, but the evidence is not necessarily strong enough yet to suggest that should be advised for all teachers.Prof Woolhouse said: ldquoIf you take the extreme view that children really donrsquot pass on this infection very much, itrsquos probably more important for the teachers to wear PPE and stop them spreading it to children, rather than the other way around.ldquoI would argue the teachers need more protecting than the children.ndash Is there an educational argument for sending Reception and Year  children back to school in June Dr Wenham said she cannot understand the motivation behind starting with the youngest pupils.She told PA: ldquoYou can think well we begin with socialisation and language development and reading all these things are developed at a very early stage.ldquoBut is a month going to make that much dference.She said it would be better for children in Years ,  or  toto make the transition into the next academic year easier, and that those in Years ,  and  were missing out on the rite of passage of leaving school.Dr Wenham added: ldquoThe summer holidays are looming, so it seems a massive health risk for very little educational gain..push,i[r].l*new story: Woman pushed into boot of car during ‘attempted abduction’Ambulance crews deal with two car crash on Armagh roadNewsTraffic and TravelCrimeWeatherPoliticsBusinessEducationHealthPeopleRead ThisCoronavirusSportFootballOther SportWhats OnArts and EntertainmentThings To DoLestyleCarsHomes and GardensNewsPoliticsCouncil welcomes fundingThe Lord Mayor of Armagh City, Banbridge and Craigavon Borough Council has welcomed the Executive’s COVID- emergency funding for local councils.By The NewsroomTuesday, th May , : pm""This morningCommunities Minister, Deirdre Hargey, informed the Assembly that the Executive had agreed to provide a total of £. million to NorthernIreland’s  councils by way of an “immediate intervention”.Speaking after the announcement was made, ABC Lord Mayor, Councillor Mealla Campbell said: “As a Council it is our priority during this crisis to protect and ensure the delivery of our basic services but like many other councils at this time, the future of these essential services such as bin collections, burials and street cleansing are threatened by loss of income“I therefore welcome this announcement of funding, which will provide some interim assistance from now until the end of June.”Editorial Image. : Other rd PartyCommunities Minister, Deirdre Hargey MLA said: “Despite the current COVID- pandemic, councils continue to play an essential role in deliveringpublic services, such as waste collection and disposal, community support, and provision of registration and cemeteryservices.“The restrictions that have been introduced, with the clear purpose of protecting le and ensuring out health service has not been overwhelmed, have created a severe financial challenge for our  councils as they have lost practically all of their self-generated income through the closure of council facilities.“This funding will help assist councils with their cash flow and support them in the delivery of the vital services they are providing to the community at this time.“It will also help ensure that they are ready to play their key role in our post-pandemic recovery and limit the financial impact on ratepayers going forward.”While the additional funding is welcomed, Armagh City, Banbridge and Craigavon Borough Council’s Lord Mayor said more will need to be done to ensure council’s can help communities to recover.“It is a first step but it is clear that further investment in local government will be required to ensure that Council are not only in a position to provide continuity of service to our ratepayers but that we are able to help our communities recover,” said the Lord Mayor.“The executive must look at longer term investment to support the financial resilience of our councils so that we are resourced to deliver on strategies for bespoke economic recovery and community support.“Councils will be in the frontline of transformation post COVID- and it is a priority that we are equipped to deal with the signicant body of work ahead.“Meanwhile a spokesperson for Armagh City, Banbridge and Craigavon Borough Council said Council will continue to ensure vital public services are protected.“Council welcomes the announcement by Communities Minister Deirdre Hargey, and will continue to work with the Minister, and colleagues across councils, to make the case for support of local government to ensure vital public services are protected,” said the spokesperson.Adam Morton , Local Democracy Reporting Service""Most Popular." data-index"" data-s-event"gaEvent" data-s-ec"navigation" data-s-ea"most popular" data-s-el"" title"" has just been issued from the four UK Chief Medical Officers on an update to coronavirus symptoms. “From today, all iniduals should self-isolatethey develop a new continuous cough or fever or anosmia. “Anosmia is the loss or a change in your normal sense of smell. It can also affect your sense of taste as the two are closely linked. “We have been closely monitoring the emerging data and evidence on COVID- and after thorough consideration, we are now confident enough to recommend this new measure. “The inidual’s household should also self-isolate for  days as per the current guidelines and the inidual should stay at home for seven days, or longerthey still have symptoms other than cough or loss of sense of smell or taste, they said. The statement is signed by Chief Medical Officer for Wales, Dr Frank Atherton, Chief Medical Officer for Northern Ireland, Dr Michael McBride, Chief Medical Officer for Scotland, Dr Gregor Smith and Chief Medical Officer for England, Professor Chris Whitty. Changes for the symptomatic inidual and their household: Iniduals will need to self-isolate immediatelythey develop a new continuous cough OR fever OR as of today, a loss or changed sense of normal smell or taste . All members of their household must also self-isolate according to current guidelines, unless the symptomatic inidual receives a negative test result.  addthis, Leave your commentTyrone Constitution- title: coronavirus morning update
story: NORTHERN Ireland Executive ministers and their officials have over the past  hours been involved in a number of initiatives and critical decisions relating to the Coronavirus emergency. A poundmillion rates relief package for business sectors hit hardest by the Covid- lockdown was announced by the Finance Minister Conor Murphy today. Building on the poundmillion scheme announced in March which gave all businesses a threemonth rates holiday, the new scheme will result in businesses in the following sectors being relieved of the obligation to pay rates for the full financial year up to  March : * hospitality, tourism and leisure* retail * childcare* Belfast City, Belfast International and City of Derry Airports. All businesses will also receive a one-month extension of the rates holiday up to  July . Minister Murphy confirmed: “The pandemic has had a devastating impact on the economy. The initial rates support package helped businesses with immediate cash-flow dficulties during the lockdown. As the Executive begins to ease the restrictions which have been necessary to save lives, I am pleased to announce this new scheme which importantly provides all businesses with an extended rates holiday for July. “Further support is then targeted at the sectors which will be in greatest need in the months ahead. This includes retail, hospitality, tourism, leisure, childcare and airports. This rates package, which is aligned with the Executive’s pathway to recovery, brings the total support for businesses from rates relief and grants to almost poundmillion.” Education Minister Peter Weir welcomed the Executive’s approval of an income scheme to support substitute teachers who are unable to access secure work during the Covid- shutdown of schools. With many schools closed during the pandemic except those supervising vulnerable pupils and the children of key workers, eligible substitute teachers, who were engaged between  January  to  March , will have access to an income for the period April to June . An additional income through this scheme will top up their income to at least % of that earned in the period. Minister Weir acknowledged: “I am fully aware of the signicant impact this pandemic has had on our pupils, teaching and non-teaching staff. The issue of funding for substitute teachers, who are unable to work and therefore unable to be paid, is one that and I, and my Department, have been working hard to resolve. Today, I am pleased to announce that we will be introducing an income support scheme for substitute teachers through the Covid- Response fund. The estimated total cost of the scheme is around poundmillion. My Department will allocate up to poundmillion and the Executive has agreed to fund the remaining poundmillion. I would also like to thank the Finance Minister for his support in this matter. Communities Minister Deirdre Hargey announced the Executive had allocated an additional poundmillion to support the most vulnerable people in housing during the Covid- emergency. The Supporting People Programme provides housing support for approximately , vulnerable iniduals living independently including: homeless people, older people, young people, and people with physical disabilities, learning disabilities and mental health issues. The additional funds will help maintain Supporting People services, which are commissioned by the Housing Executive and delivered through the public and voluntary and community sectors. Minister Hargey explained: “The additional funding will be used to address signicant staff shortages in the immediate term and mounting pressure in this area,the number of Covid- cases continues to increase. The money will fund overtime costs for existing staff and the use of the bank or agency staffing that is necessaryservices are to be maintained. Extra cleaning is also required, and the matter of a sufficient and adequate supply of PPE is being addressed.  “These are unusual times which demand actions and solutions. This funding allocation represents our commitment to the vulnerable people in Supporting People schemes, and the staff providing support to them. We support them and we are working hard to ensure their safety and wellbeing.” The allocation was also welcomed by Health Minister Robin Swann who added: “It is well recognised that supported living services better enable people to live to their full potential and reduce the need for acute health and social care services. Their value in society cannot be underestimated. “Officials across both departments are in regular communication to identy and address Covid- priorities across our Supporting People schemes. As a result my Department has now extended Covid- testing to all staff and residents of Supporting People schemes as well as providing a temporary supply of Personal Protective Equipment.” It was revealed by Minister Hargey that local councils will also be given pound.million to alleviate financial pressures as a result of the Covid- restrictions. The funding will ensure councils can continue to provide essential services and support those in need. Minister Hargey said: “Despite the current Covid- pandemic, councils continue to play an essential role in delivering essential services such as waste collection and disposal, community support, and provision of registration and cemetery services. The restrictions that have been introduced, with the clear purpose of protecting le and ensuring our health service has not been overwhelmed, have created a severe financial challenge for our  councils as they have lost practically all of their self-generated income through the closure of council facilities. “This funding will help assist councils with their cash flow and support them in the delivery of the vital services they are providing to the community at this time but will also help ensure that they are ready to play their key role in our post-pandemic recovery and limit the financial impact on ratepayers going forward.” The Minister previously announced that councils here are eligible to apply to furlough staff through the Coronavirus Job Retention Scheme. This will help ensure that the rights of workers are respected and jobs are protected. This scheme along with this additional funding are supporting councils through this period.  addthis, Leave your commentTyrone Constitution- High Street, OmaghBT BDTel:    n n nHome n n nNews n n
